intro: Calamus halmaherensis, commonly known as the Halmahera calamus, is a species of flowering plant in the family Arales. It is native to the island of Halmahera in Indonesia, where it thrives in humid, tropical environments. The plant is characterized by its tall, slender stems and long, narrow leaves that are often used in traditional crafts. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically followed by spore-bearing cones. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Calamus halmaherensis is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
